_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SuperCool Warehousing is a complex of freezer warehouse buildings used for temporary freezer storage of food grade items destined for truck transport to retail outlets. The refrigerant used to cool the freezer is ammonia. Ammonia is a hazardous substance (toxic) and its use in large quantities in industries is regulated by the EPA. SuperCool refrigeration system T6 B contains 28,368 lbs.

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies-
SuperCool policy demands a proactive approach to equipment maintenance. Equipment failure is the primary hazard facing a refrigerated storage facility. Frequent monitoring of equipment reduces the chances of an accidental release. SuperCool uses a rigorous inspection program to ensure that equipment is functioning properly and pays close attention to routine equipment maintenance. SuperCool employs only 2-3 people to work on the refrigeration process. Much of the equipment maintenance is performed by licensed contracting companies.

SuperCool refrigeration employees have received "Hazardous Materials Technician" & "First Responder" training and they are annually refreshed. The Emergency Response (ER) Plan includes notification of potentially affected neighbors. SuperCool extends their inspection/maintenance program to include emergency equipment as well.

Worst- Case Scenario and Alternate Scenario or Accidental Release-
A Worst-Case release scenario was constructed for ammonia system T6 B. An EPA model was used in which the release occurs in the outdoor high pressure receiver and then migrates to the surrounding community. Should a major refrigeration line be significantly damaged or a major piece of equipment seriously malfunction and 4,220 lbs. of ammonia are released from this systems largest vessel, an area within approximately 0.43 miles of the facility could potentially be affected.

A much more likely scenario involves a lifting safety relief valve from T6 B that requires 10 minutes to stop. This release was also modeled u

sing EPA guidance. In this scenario approximately 920 lbs. of ammonia would be released and expected to travel approximately 0.2 miles from the source.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps-
SuperCool adheres to 29 CFR1910.119 (OSHA's PSM regulation) and thoroughly documents inspections and maintenance procedures. All SuperCool refrigeration employees are trained per the requirements of 29 CFR1910.120 and training is refreshed annually.

Emergency Response Plan-
SuperCool has coordinated its ER plan with the local authority (District VII) and the Polk County Fire Department & Hazmat Team (PCFDHM) The PCFDHM conducted a full dress rehearsal of a mock emergency response in June 1998 in order to acquaint themselves with the facility should a ER action ever be required. The local Police/Fire authorities will assist in notification of nearby citizenry in the event of a catastrophic release.

SuperCool conducts monthly inspections of their Emergency Response equipment to ensure that all equipment is functioning properly.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety-
Super Cool plans to install automatic ammonia leak monitors to improve their leak detection capabilities.
